t: When*p the wall had been rebuilt and I had the doors installed, the gatekeepers, singers, and Levites were appointed.
Then I put my brother Hanani in charge of Jerusalem, along with Hananiah, commander of the fortress, because he was a faithful man who feared God more than most.

I said to them, “Do not open the gates of Jerusalem until the sun is hot, and let the doors be shut and securely fastened while the guards are on duty. Station the citizens of Jerusalem as guards, some at their posts and some at their homes.”
The*p city was large and spacious, but there were few people in it, and no houses had been built yet.

Then my God put it into my mind to assemble the nobles, the officials, and the people to be registered by genealogy. I found the genealogical record of those who came back first, and I found the following written in it:
These*p are the people of the province who went up among the captive exiles deported by King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon. Each of them returned to Jerusalem and Judah, to his own town.
They came with Zerubbabel, Jeshua, Nehemiah, Azariah, Raamiah, Nahamani, Mordecai, Bilshan, Mispereth, Bigvai, Nehum, and Baanah. The*p number of the Israelite men included
Pahath-moab’s*le descendants: Jeshua’s*le and Joab’s descendants 2,818*lg
The*p priests included Jedaiah’s*le descendants of the house of Jeshua 973*lg
The*p Levites included Jeshua’s*le descendants: of Kadmiel Hodevah’s*le descendants 74.*lg
The*p gatekeepers included Shallum’s*le descendants, Ater’s descendants, Talmon’s*le descendants, Akkub’s descendants, Hatita’s*le descendants, Shobai’s descendants 138.*lg
The*p temple servants included Ziha’s*ln descendants, Hasupha’s descendants, Tabbaoth’s*ln descendants,
Keros’s descendants, Sia’s*ln descendants, Padon’s descendants,
Lebanah’s*ln descendants, Hagabah’s descendants, Shalmai’s*ln descendants,
Hanan’s descendants, Giddel’s*ln descendants, Gahar’s descendants,
Reaiah’s*ln descendants, Rezin’s descendants, Nekoda’s*ln descendants,
Gazzam’s descendants, Uzza’s*ln descendants, Paseah’s descendants,
Besai’s*ln descendants, Meunim’s descendants, Nephishesim’s*ln descendants,
Bakbuk’s descendants, Hakupha’s*ln descendants, Harhur’s descendants,
Bazlith’s*ln descendants, Mehida’s descendants, Harsha’s*ln descendants,
Barkos’s descendants, Sisera’s*ln descendants, Temah’s descendants,
The*p descendants of Solomon’s servants included Sotai’s*ln descendants, Sophereth’s descendants, Perida’s*ln descendants,
Jaala’s descendants, Darkon’s*ln descendants, Giddel’s descendants,
Shephatiah’s*ln descendants, Hattil’s descendants, Pochereth-hazzebaim’s*ln descendants, Amon’s descendants.
All*le the temple servants and*le the descendants of Solomon’s servants 392.*lg
The*p following are those who came from Tel-melah, Tel-harsha, Cherub, Addon, and Immer, but were unable to prove that their ancestral families and their lineage were Israelite:
Delaiah’s*le descendants, Tobiah’s*le descendants, and*le Nekoda’s descendants 642*lg

and*p from the priests: the descendants of Hobaiah, the descendants of Hakkoz, and the descendants of Barzillai — who had taken a wife from the daughters of Barzillai the Gileadite and who bore their name.
These searched for their entries in the genealogical records, but they could not be found, so they were disqualified from the priesthood.
The governor ordered them not to eat the most holy things until there was a priest who could consult the Urim and Thummim.
not*le including their 7,337 male and female servants, as*le well as their 245 male and female singers.
Some*p of the family heads contributed to the project. The governor gave 1,000 gold coins, 50 bowls, and 530 priestly garments to the treasury.
Some of the family heads gave 20,000 gold coins and 2,200 silver minas to the treasury for the project.
The rest of the people gave 20,000 gold coins, 2,000 silver minas, and 67 priestly garments.
The priests, Levites, gatekeepers, temple singers, some of the people, temple servants, and all Israel settled in their towns.
When*p the seventh month came and the Israelites had settled in their towns,
